This branch of the family called the [[Gong clan of Qufu]] received [[Korean nobility|aristocratic rank]] in [[Joseon]] era Korea.{{cite web|url=http://www.qz.gov.cn/English/Recent/201405/t20140519_278510.htm|title=Descendants of Confucius in South Korea Seek Roots in Quzhou|last=|first=|date=19 May 2014|website=Quzhou.China|archiveurl=https://archive.is/Y9cKG|archivedate=4 February 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2014-08-05}}{{cite web|url=http://en.people.cn/90001/90777/90851/6355971.html|title=South Korea home to 80,000 descendants of Confucius - People's Daily Online|first=|last=english@peopledaily.com.cn|website=en.people.cn}}{{cite web|url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/features/content_16696029_4.htm|title=New Confucius Genealogy out next year -- china.org.cn|website=www.china.org.cn}}{{cite web|url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/Off_the_Wire/2016-03/11/content_37999541.htm|title=China Exclusive: Korean Confucius descendants trace back to ancestor of family tree - China.org.cn|website=www.china.org.cn}}{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-03/11/c_135179011.htm|title=China Exclusive: Korean Confucius descendants trace back to ancestor of family tree|last=|first=|date=|website=news.xinhuanet.com|access-date=}} [[w:zh:曲阜孔氏 (朝鲜半岛)|曲阜孔氏 (朝鲜半岛)]] [[w:ko:곡부 공씨|곡부 공씨]] The Liyang Kongs were descendants of Confucius who lived in southern China during the Yuan dynasty's final years. 孔克齊 Kong Keqi or 孔齊 Kong Qi was a scion of the 55th generation.Smith, Paul J. "Fear of Gynarchy in an Age of Chaos: Kong Qi's Reflections on Life in South China under Mongol Rule." Journal of the Economic and Social History of the Orient 41, no. 1 (1998): 1-95. https://www.jstor.org/stable/3632774. https://www.jstor.org/stable/3632774 http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/1568520982601412 An account was written by Kong Qi on this era.{{cite book|title=Modern Chinese Religion I (2 vol.set): Song-Liao-Jin-Yuan (960-1368 AD)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y2DiBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1466#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=8 December 2014|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-27164-7|pages=1466–}} {{cite book|title=Modern Chinese Religion I (2 vol.set): Song-Liao-Jin-Yuan (960-1368 AD)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y2DiBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1575#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=8 December 2014|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-27164-7|pages=1575–}} ===Ming dynasty (1368–1644)=== In 1506, the [[Zhengde Emperor]] (r. 1505–1521) appointed Kong Yansheng (孔彥繩), a member of the southern branch, as a "''Wujing Boshi''" ([[w:zh:五經博士|五經博士]]; "Professor of the [[Four Books and Five Classics|Five Classics]]") in the [[Hanlin Academy]].{{cite book|author=Thomas A. Wilson|title=On Sacred Grounds: Culture, Society, Politics, and the Formation of the Cult of Confucius|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4XXAAAAMAAJ&q=wujing+boshi+descendant&dq=wujing+boshi+descendant&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN-7-vjpXMAhUGFz4KHQBfDTYQ6AEIMTAE|year=2002|publisher=Harvard University Asia Center|isbn=978-0-674-00961-5|pages=69,315}}{{cite book|author1=Thomas Jansen|author2=Thoralf Klein|author3=Christian Meyer|title=Globalization and the Making of Religious Modernity in China: Transnational Religions, Local Agents, and the Study of Religion, 1800-Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GNlXAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA188&dq=wujing+boshi+descendant&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN-7-vjpXMAhUGFz4KHQBfDTYQ6AEINDAF#v=onepage&q=wujing%20boshi%20descendant&f=false|date=21 March 2014|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-27151-7|pages=188–}} The appointment was equivalent to that of an eighth-grade official in the Ming imperial administration. Kong Yansheng's descendants were allowed to inherit the title "Wujing Boshi". (1592-1647) 孔胤植 Kong Yinzhi 孔貞叢 in 1609 Kong Zhencong in 1552 孔弘干 Kong Honggan 闕里誌 all edited the Queli zhi genealogy.{{cite book|title=Modern Chinese Religion I (2 vol.set): Song-Liao-Jin-Yuan (960-1368 AD)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y2DiBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1565#v=onepage&q&f=falsee|date=8 December 2014|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-27164-7|pages=1565–}} ===Qing dynasty (1644–1912)=== On 31 October 1644, the [[Shunzhi Emperor]] (r. 1643–1661) of the [[Manchu people|Manchu]]-led [[Qing dynasty]] confirmed and recognised the legitimacies of the Duke Yansheng and Wujing Boshi titles after the Qing capital was established in [[Beijing]] following the [[Qing conquest of the Ming|Qing conquest of China]].{{cite book|author=Frederic E. Wakeman|title=The Great Enterprise: The Manchu Reconstruction of Imperial Order in Seventeenth-century China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA858|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04804-1|pages=858–}}{{cite book|author=Evelyn S. Rawski|title=The Last Emperors: A Social History of Qing Imperial Institutions|date=15 November 1998|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-92679-0|pages=72–}} [[w:zh:毕沅|毕沅]] Bi Yuan's, 李长森 Li Changsen's and 方受畴 Fang Shouchou's (nephew of [[Fang Guancheng]]) female progeny married [[w:zh:孔繁灏|孔繁灏]] Kong Fanhao.{{cite book|title=A History of Food Culture in China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLPACwAAQBAJ&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=23 July 2015|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-1-938368-27-1|pages=24–}}{{cite book|author1=Rongguang Zhao|author2=Gangliu Wang|author3=Aimee Yiran Wang|title=A History of Food Culture in China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nn3FCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=1 January 2015|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-1-938368-28-8|pages=24–}} Kong Luhua (relative of the Duke Yansheng) was the second wife of [[Ruan Yuan]].{{cite book|author=Betty Peh-T'I Wei|title=Ruan Yuan, 1764-1849: The Life and Work of a Major Scholar-Official in Nineteenth-Century China before the Opium War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8lxUMoR5TXcC&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q=kong%20luhua&f=false|date=1 August 2006|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn=978-962-209-785-8|pages=246–}} Headgear was worn by Kong Lingyi in an official portrait.{{cite book|title=Selling Modernity: A Study of "All-Story Monthly" ("Yueyue Xiaoshuo") in the Late Qing Context|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w_7v5DScKh8C&pg=PA74&dq=kong+hat+hide+queue&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiOsYiAxtnOAhVCGh4KHYH2AMUQ6AEIHjAA|year=2008|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-549-65016-4|pages=74–}} ===Republic of China (1912–present)=== After the 1911 [[Xinhai Revolution]] which overthrew the [[Manchu people|Manchu]]-led [[Qing dynasty]], most of the nobility titles used in the imperial era were abolished. The Duke Yansheng title, however, was an exception along with the Marquis of Extended Grace and the descendants of Mencius, Zengzi, and Yan Hui. During the revolution, some Westerners were told that a [[Han Chinese]] would be installed as the emperor. The candidate was either the bearer of the Duke Yansheng title,{{cite book|author=Eiko Woodhouse|title=The Chinese Hsinhai Revolution: G. E. Morrison and Anglo-Japanese Relations, 1897-1920|date=2 August 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-35242-5|pages=113}}{{cite book|author=Jonathan D. Spence|title=The Gate of Heavenly Peace: The Chinese and Their Revolution|date=28 October 1982|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-101-17372-5|pages=84}}{{cite book|author1=Shêng Hu|author2=Danian Liu|title=The 1911 Revolution: A Retrospective After 70 Years|year=1983|publisher=New World Press|page=55}}{{cite book|title=The National Review, China|year=1913|page=200}}{{cite book|title=Monumenta Serica|year=1967|publisher=H. Vetch|page=67}} or the holder of the title "[[Marquis of Extended Grace]]", a title granted to descendants of the imperial family of the [[Ming dynasty]].{{cite book|author=Percy Horace Braund Kent|title=The Passing of the Manchus|year=1912|publisher=E. Arnold|pages=382–}} The Duke Yansheng was proposed for replacing the Qing dynasty as Emperor by [[Liang Qichao]].{{cite book |last= |first= |date=2014 |title=Modernisation of Chinese Culture: Continuity and Change |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ECJQBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA74#v=onepage&q&f=false |location= |publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing |edition=revised |page=74 |isbn=1443867721 |author-link= }} In 1913, the [[Beiyang government]], led by [[Yuan Shikai]], passed a law allowing the Duke Yansheng title to be retained and held by Kong Lingyi (孔令貽), a member of the northern branch. The Wujing Boshi title, on the other hand, was renamed to "Dacheng Zhisheng Xianshi Nanzong Fengsi Guan" (大成至聖先師南宗奉祀官) and held by Kong Qingyi (孔慶儀), a member of the southern branch. Yuan Shikai conferred the title of Prince on the Duke immediately before declaring the [[Empire of China (1915–16)]].{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/chinaherhistoryd00park|title=China, her history, diplomacy, and commerce, from the earliest times to the present day|first=Edward Harper|last=Parker|date=14 February 2018|publisher=N.Y. : Dutton|via=Internet Archive}} The regent for the underage Duke Kong Te-cheng was Kong Lingjun 孔令儁.{{cite web|url=http://lishi.zhuixue.net/renwu/kangyouwei/26387.html|title=第22章 康有为与孔令儁_中国历史网|website=lishi.zhuixue.net}} He was the Kong Family Mansion steward.{{cite book|title=A History of Food Culture in China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLPACwAAQBAJ&pg=PA21#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=23 July 2015|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-1-938368-27-1|pages=21–}}{{cite book|author1=Rongguang Zhao|author2=Gangliu Wang|author3=Aimee Yiran Wang|title=A History of Food Culture in China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nn3FCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA21#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=1 January 2015|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-1-938368-28-8|pages=21–}} In 1935, the [[Nationalist government]] abolished the hereditary peerage systems of the imperial era and converted the Duke Yansheng title into a political office, "Dacheng Zhisheng Xianshi Fengsi Guan" (大成至聖先師奉祀官), which simply means "Sacrificial Official to Confucius".{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90782/99727/6936558.html|title=Confucius - People's Daily Online|website=english.people.com.cn}} During the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] (1937–1945), [[Kung Te-cheng]] (Kong Decheng), the Sacrificial Official to Confucius, evacuated to [[Hankou]], [[Wuhan]], where he was received by [[H. H. Kung|Kung Hsiang-hsi]] (Kong Xiangxi), a fellow descendant of Confucius.{{cite news |title=Foreign News: Warlike Confucian|author= |newspaper=TIME|date=Jan 17, 1938|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,758870,00.html}} They moved to [[Chongqing]] later, where the Nationalist government was based during the war. After the victory of the Communists in the Chinese Civil War, Kung Te-cheng evacuated with the Nationalist government to Taiwan where the current Sacrificial Official to Confucius is based. Until 2008, the office of "Sacrificial Official to Confucius" had the same ranking and remuneration as that of a cabinet minister in the [[government of the Republic of China]] in Taiwan. On the other hand, Yan Shiyung (顏世鏞, the last Sacrificial Official to [[Yan Hui]], 1903-1975) and Kung Xiangkai (孔祥楷, the last Dacheng Zhisheng Xianshi Nanzong Fengsi Guan, 1938-) didn't move to Taiwan, so their title was abolished after the establishment of [[People's Republic of China]].{{cite web|url=http://www.qfsq.com/news/view.asp?id=3694|title=曲阜市情网－第二章　　近现代名人|website=www.qfsq.com}}https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E5%AD%94%E7%A5%A5%E6%A5%B7 In 1998, the Taiwanese government demolished the office building of the sacrificial official but retained the appointment. The hostel of [[National Chung Hsing University]] along Guoguang Road in [[South District, Taichung|South District]], [[Taichung]] is situated at the former location of the office building. In 2008, with approval from the Kong family, Taiwan's [[Ministry of the Interior (Taiwan)|Ministry of the Interior]] converted the sacrificial official appointment into an unpaid one. The office is currently held by [[Kung Tsui-chang]] (Kong Chuichang), a 79th-generation descendant of Confucius who was appointed in September 2009 after the death of his grandfather, Kung Te-cheng. The Ministry of Interior also declared that female descendants of Confucius are eligible for future appointment. The southern branch still remained in Quzhou where they lived to this day, and the title of . Confucius's descendants in Quzhou alone number 30,000.{{cite news|title=Confucius Anniversary Celebrated|url=http://www.china.org.cn/english/2006/Sep/182656.htm|agency=China Daily|date=September 29, 2006}} The leader of the southern branch is 孔祥楷 (Kong Xiangkai), a 75th-generation descendant of Confucius.{{cite book|author1=Thomas Jansen|author2=Thoralf Klein|author3=Christian Meyer|title=Globalization and the Making of Religious Modernity in China: Transnational Religions, Local Agents, and the Study of Religion, 1800-Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GNlXAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA189#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=21 March 2014|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-27151-7|pages=189–}} Traditionally, the descendants of Confucius use [[Generation name#Generation poem|generation poems]] for their names given to them by the Ming and Qing Emperors along with the descendants of the other [[Four Sages]] [[w:zh:四氏|四氏]].{{zh icon}} [http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20031203183333/ 孔姓 (The Kong family, descendents of Confucius)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903010033/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20031203183333/ |date=September 3, 2011 }}{{zh icon}} [http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20040216142301 孟姓 (The Meng family, descendents of Mencius)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060116060231/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20040216142301 |date=January 16, 2006 }} However, Yan family, one of the Four Sages and descendants of [[Yanyuan]], didn't use the poem eventually because Yanyuan is considered to be a possible maternal cousin of Confucius, so [[Emperor Yingzong of Ming]] made another generation poem for Yan family.{{cite book|title=颜子家世|last=|first=|publisher=齐鲁书社|year=1998|isbn=9787533307400|location=|pages=|language=Chinese|trans-title=Family of Yanyuan}} ==See also== * [[Family tree of Confucius in the main line of descent]] * [[Song (state)]] - Confucius was traditionally believed to be descended from the Shang dynasty Kings through the Dukes of Song * [[Shang dynasty]] * [[Descent from antiquity]] * [[Hanlin Academy#Academy members|Other holders of the title Wujing Boshi]] * [[Marquis of Extended Grace]] - Ming dynasty descendants ==References== {{commons category|Tombs of the Ming Dukes of Yansheng}} {{Reflist|30em}} * {{cite journal |last1=Wilson |first1=Thomas A. |last2= |first2= |date=August 1996 |title=The Ritual Formation of Confucian Orthodoxy and the Descendants of the Sage |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/248653434_The_Ritual_Formation_of_Confucian_Orthodoxy_and_the_Descendants_of_the_Sage |journal=The Journal of Asian Studies |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=559–584 |doi= |access-date= }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.strategicstudies.org/Monarchy%20Center/Reports/Jan%2027%2017%20-%20Confucius.htm |title= Descendant of the Sage in China The Rôle of the Sacrificial Official to Confucius |last=Marschik |first=Quinn |date= January 27, 2017 |website=The Center For the Study of Monarchy, Traditional Governance, and Sovereignty |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}} * {{cite journal |last1=Sohigian|first1=Diran John |last2= |first2= |date=January 2011 |title= Confucius and the Lady in Question: Power Politics, Cultural Production and the Performance of Confucius Saw Nanzi in China in 1929 |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/653479 |journal=Twentieth-Century China |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages= 23–43 |publisher=Shih Chieng University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan |doi=10.1353/tcc.2011.0005|access-date= }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yansheng, Duke}} [[Category:Chinese nobility]] [[Category:Qufu]] [[Category:Confucianism]] [[Category:Descendants of Confucius]]
